org.jukito

Class TestModule

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.google.inject.AbstractModule
      • org.jukito.TestModule
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Module
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    JukitoModule

    public abstract class TestModule
extends AbstractModule
    A guice Module with a bit of syntactic sugar to bind within typical test scopes. Depends on mockito.

    Depends on Mockito.

    Author:
    Philippe Beaudoin

      • bindMock

        protected <T> ScopedBindingBuilder bindMock(Class<T> klass)
        Binds an interface to a mocked version of itself. You will usually want to bind this in the TestSingleton scope.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the interface to bind
        Parameters:
        klass - The class to bind
        Returns:
        A ScopedBindingBuilder.

      • bindMock

        protected <T> ScopedBindingBuilder bindMock(TypeLiteral<T> typeLiteral)
        Binds an interface annotated with a @Named to a mocked version of itself. You will usually want to bind this in the TestSingleton scope.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the interface to bind, a parameterized type
        Parameters:
        typeLiteral - The TypeLiteral corresponding to the parameterized type to bind.
        Returns:
        A ScopedBindingBuilder.

        Returns:

      • bindManyInstances

        protected <T,V extends T> void bindManyInstances(Class<T> clazz,
                                     V... instances)
        This method binds many different instances to the same class or interface. Use this only if the instances are totally stateless. That is, they are immutable and have no mutable dependencies (e.g. a String or a simple POJO). For more complex classes use bindMany(java.lang.Class<T>, java.lang.Class<? extends T>...).

        The specified Class will be bound to all the different instances, each binding using a different unique annotation.

        This method is useful when combined with the @All annotation.

        Parameters:
        clazz - The Class to which the instances will be bound.
        instances - All the instances to bind.

      • bindManyInstances

        protected <T,V extends T> void bindManyInstances(TypeLiteral<T> type,
                                     V... instances)
        This method binds many different instances to the same type literal. Use this only if the instances are totally stateless. That is, they are immutable and have no mutable dependencies (e.g. a String or a simple POJO). For more complex classes use bindMany(java.lang.Class<T>, java.lang.Class<? extends T>...).

        The specified TypeLiteral will be bound to all the different instances, each binding using a different unique annotation.

        This method is useful when combined with the @All annotation.

        Parameters:
        type - The TypeLiteral to which the instances will be bound.
        instances - All the instances to bind.

      • bindMany

        protected <T> void bindMany(Class<T> clazz,
                Class<? extends T>... boundClasses)
        This method binds many different classes to the same interface. All the classes will be bound within the TestScope.SINGLETON scope.

        This method is useful when combined with the @All annotation.

        Parameters:
        clazz - The Class to which the instances will be bound.
        boundClasses - All the classes to bind.

      • bindMany

        protected <T,V extends T> void bindMany(TypeLiteral<T> type,
                            TypeLiteral<? extends T>... boundTypes)
        This method binds many different type litterals to the same type litteral. All the classes will be bound within the TestScope.SINGLETON scope.

        This method is useful when combined with the @All annotation.

        Parameters:
        type - The Class to which the instances will be bound.
        boundTypes - All the types to bind.
